questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is admitted to the ICU after experiencing a cardiac arrest. CT imaging is given below. What is this radiological finding called?
questions.solution:
The CT imaging shows "White Cerebellum Sign" is seen in severe global hypoperfusion where the cerebral hemispheres are diffusely hypoattenuated, but the cerebellum and brainstem remain unaffected, appearing hyperattenuated relative to the cerebral hemispheres.

 

Global cerebral hypoperfusion

Epidemiology
  • Older children: drowning and asphyxiation.
  • Adults: cardiac arrest or cerebrovascular disease, leading to secondary hypoxemia or hypoperfusion.

Clinical Presentation
  • Patients typically present after an acute event (e.g., near-drowning, asphyxia, cardiac/respiratory arrest).

Pathology
  • Severe global hypoxic-ischemic injury
  • Grey matter is particularly vulnerable to injury because of its high metabolic demands for oxygen and glucose, along with its abundance of postsynaptic glutamate receptors, which make it more prone to excitotoxicity from excessive glutamate stimulation.

Radiological findings
  • Diffuse edema with effacement of CSF-containing spaces

 

Reversal Sign: (Option A ruled out)

  • Involves the reversal of normal CT attenuation between grey and white matter.
  • Linked to distension of deep medullary veins due to partial venous outflow obstruction from elevated intracranial pressure.
  • White matter appears of higher attenuation than grey matter.

White Cerebellum Sign: (Option B ruled out)

  • Seen with diffuse edema and hypoattenuation of cerebral hemispheres, sparing the cerebellum and brainstem.
  • Makes the cerebellum and brainstem appear hyperattenuated relative to cerebral hemispheres.
  • Pseudo subarachnoid hemorrhage (Option C): caused by cerebral edema, reduced parenchymal attenuation, swelling, and engorged superficial venous structures, leading to the subarachnoid space appearing hyperdense, mimicking a hemorrhage.
  • Both the reversal sign and the white cerebellum sign are associated with severe brain injury and poor neurological outcomes.

 

Delta Sign (Option D) is associated with certain types of intracranial hemorrhage and does not apply to the diffuse hypoattenuation of the cerebral hemispheres in this patient.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, vomiting, and right-sided weakness. Additionally, he exhibits altered sensorimotor integration and difficulty with voluntary movement control. His blood pressure is recorded at 190/110 mmHg. A CT scan of the head is performed with findings given below Based on the findings, Which artery is most likely involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The lenticulostriate arteries, which are small perforating arteries that branch off the middle cerebral artery, are frequently involved in hypertensive hemorrhages. These arteries supply deep brain structures, including the basal ganglia and internal capsule, which are critical for motor control. The patient's presentation of right-sided weakness and difficulties with voluntary movement control aligns with the involvement of these areas, making the lenticulostriate artery the most likely vessel affected.

Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage (IPH) refers to bleeding that occurs within the brain parenchyma.

 

Imaging Findings:


On NCCT, intraparenchymal hemorrhage appears as a hyperdense lesion. The hemorrhage can typically be localized in regions such as the basal ganglia, particularly in the putamen and the internal capsule, which are critical for motor control and other functions.

 

Etiology:

Common Causes:

  • Hypertension: Chronic high blood pressure is a primary risk factor, often causing small Bouchard aneurysms in the lenticulostriate arteries that supply the basal ganglia.
  • Trauma

Less Common Causes:

  • Arteriovenous Malformations (AVMs) seen in younger individuals.
  • Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy, commonly seen in elderly patients.

 

Common Sites of Hemorrhage:
The most frequent site of intraparenchymal hemorrhage is the putamen, part of the basal ganglia, although other areas like the thalamus and the internal capsule may also be affected.

 

Anterior choroidal artery (Option A): This artery supplies some deep brain structures but is not typically associated with hypertensive hemorrhages. Hemorrhages from this artery would more likely affect areas like the internal capsule, causing motor deficits but less commonly involve the deep structures described.

 

Posterior cerebral artery (OptionC): This artery primarily supplies the occipital lobe, and its involvement typically causes visual deficits rather than motor weakness or hemorrhage in the deep brain regions described.

 

Middle meningeal artery (Option D): While this artery supplies the dura mater and can be involved in epidural hematomas.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with bilateral thalamic and basal ganglia symptoms, including motor weakness and sensory disturbances. MRI reveals bilateral infarcts in these regions. Which type of venous thrombosis is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Internal cerebral veins drain the thalamus and basal ganglia. Thrombosis here can lead to bilateral infarcts in these regions, resulting in the motor and sensory symptoms observed in the patient.

 

Venous Infarction territories

 

Key distribution patterns:

  • B/L Thalamic and basal ganglia involvement in internal cerebral vein/straight sinus thrombosis. (Option B)
  • Affected posterolateral temporal lobe and inferior parietal lobule in the vein of Labbé/lateral venous sinus thrombosis. (Option C & D)
  • B/L asymmetric cortical and subcortical lesions in superior sagittal sinus occlusion. (Option A)

 

Venous Anatomy

Cerebral veins are categorized into external (superficial) and internal veins, draining the outer and inner regions of the cerebral hemisphere.

External Cerebral Veins
  • Superior Cerebral Veins: Typically 8 to 12 in number, these veins drain the upper parts of the hemisphere, entering the superior sagittal sinus after piercing the arachnoid mater.
  • Middle Cerebral Veins: Comprising four veins (two superficial and two deep), these veins drain the lateral sulcus, connecting to the cavernous sinus, superior sagittal sinus (Trolard), and transverse sinus (Labbe). The deep veins merge with the anterior cerebral vein to form the basal vein.
  • Inferior Cerebral Veins: Numerous smaller veins that drain the inferior surfaces of the hemisphere into nearby dural venous sinuses.

Additional Veins
  • Anterior Cerebral Vein: Drains parts of the medial surface alongside the anterior cerebral artery.
  • Basal Vein (of Rosenthal): Formed by the anterior cerebral, deep middle cerebral, and striate veins, this vein runs around the midbrain and drains into the great cerebral vein (of Galen), receiving tributaries from various brain structures.

Internal Cerebral Veins
  • Located on either side of the midline in the tela choroidea of the 3rd ventricle.
  • Formed at the interventricular foramen (of Monro) by the thalamostriate, septal, and choroidal veins.
  • Drain specific brain regions:
    • Thalamostriate (thalamus and basal ganglia)
    • Septal (septum pellucidum)
    • Choroidal (choroid plexus).
  • Unite beneath the splenium of the corpus callosum to form the great cerebral vein.

Great Cerebral Vein of Galen
  • A single vein (about 2 cm long) formed by the internal cerebral veins.
  • Receives basal veins and joins the inferior sagittal sinus to form the straight sinus.
  • Tributaries include:
    • Internal cerebral veins
    • Basal veins
    • Veins from the colliculi (tectum of the midbrain)
    • Veins from the cerebellum and adjacent occipital lobes

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a severe headache that started 2 days ago. She reports associated symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and a few episodes of seizure. A history of recent oral contraceptive use is present. On examination, she has a mild altered mental status but no focal deficits. A CECT is given below. What specific sign on CT is characteristic of this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CECT shows the empty delta sign which is a characteristic finding on CECT that indicates dural venous sinus thrombosis, particularly in the superior sagittal sinus. It appears as a triangular or crescent-shaped filling defect surrounded by contrast, representing the thrombus. This finding aligns well with the clinical suspicion of CVT in this patient, given her symptoms and risk factors (H/o contraception).

 

Central venous sinus thrombosis

 
  • CVT should be suspected in patients presenting with headaches, seizures, or encephalopathy.
  • Can occur in superficial or deep dural venous sinuses, affecting either isolated veins or as part of broader venous sinus thrombosis.
  • Factors like intracranial infections, trauma, dehydration, pregnancy, oral contraceptives, smoking, and vasculitis (e.g., Behçet disease) can trigger CVT. If absent, a thrombophilia screening is necessary.

CT Findings:

  • The empty delta sign, visible in contrast-enhanced CT scans, indicates dural venous sinus thrombosis in the superior sagittal sinus as a triangular filling defect outlined by contrast, representing a thrombus. (Option A)
  • The dense vein sign, a hyperdense vessel sign indicating hyperattenuating thrombus due to acute venous thrombosis, is found in cortical veins or dural venous sinuses. (Option D)

MRI Findings:

  • Loss of normal flow void; thrombosed vessels may appear hyperintense on T1 and T2 sequences. Very acute thrombus can be hypointense on T2, mimicking flow voids. Additionally, slow flow can also result in loss of the flow void.
  • MR venography (MRV) shows a loss of flow signal or irregularity, indicating a thrombus.
  • SWI (Susceptibility Weighted Imaging) can highlight thrombosed veins and detect acute hemorrhage.

Empty theca sign (Option B)

Empty sella sign (Option C)

  • The empty thecal sac sign occurs when the thecal sac appears empty on lumbar spine MRI, particularly on T2-weighted images.
  • It is seen in Adhesive arachnoiditis.

  • It occurs when the pituitary gland is shrunken or absent, with CSF filling the sella turcica.
  • Seen in idiopathic intracranial hypertension & Sheehan's syndrome

questions.text: A 75-year-old female with a history of stroke presents for follow-up imaging 6 months after an acute right middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarct. CT head is taken and is shown below. Which of the following imaging findings is most characteristic in this case?

choices.text: T2 hypointensity in the ipsilateral corticospinal tract
High signal intensity on DWI and low signal on ADC
Enlarged sulci and ventricles with CSF-like signal intensity
Ipsilateral cerebellar volume loss due to large MCA infarcts

questions.solution:
CT scan shows chronic infarcts in the right capsulo-ganglionic region and corona radiata, along with chronic lacunar infarcts in the right thalamus. Enlarged sulci and ventricles with CSF-like signal intensity are characteristic findings of chronic infarct.

 

Chronic Infarct Radiological Imaging:

  • Development of encephalomalacia and volume loss, causing enlargement of adjacent sulci and ventricles.

CT and MRI: signal intensity approaches that of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

  • Rarely, cystic encephalomalacia can occur, sometimes with paradoxical mass effect (more common in children).
  • Wallerian degeneration: may be visible as T2 hyperintensity in the ipsilateral corticospinal tract with asymmetrical brainstem atrophy.(Option A ruled out)
  • Contralateral cerebellar volume loss can occur with large middle cerebellar artery infarcts. (Option D ruled out)
  • Dystrophic Calcification: Rarely occurs in the late phase of chronic infarction.
  • DWI and ADC Changes: DWI and ADC signal normalization occurs within 5 to 10 days (“pseudonormalization”), which can mask small infarcts.
  • Larger infarcts remain visible on structural images.
  • Prolonged diffusion restriction in small white matter infarcts may persist for weeks.
  • Mature infarcts later exhibit "free diffusion" (low signal on DWI, bright on ADC map) due to loss of structural integrity.(Option B ruled out)
  • T2 Shine-Through Effect: In mature infarcts, tissue with long T2 relaxation times (hyperintense on T2) can appear bright on DWI due to the "T2 shine-through" effect. This can be differentiated from acute infarcts as the ADC map will also be hyperintense.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presents with left-sided weakness and speech difficulty for 8 hours. NCCT shows no hemorrhage, and CTAngiography reveals a proximal MCA occlusion. DWI shows a large infarct volume (>70 ml). According to the Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) Acute Stroke Imaging Algorithm, what is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Continue with tPA infusion and monitor
Consider perfusion imaging with CT or MRI

questions.solution:
According to the MGH Acute Stroke Imaging Algorithm, if the DWI lesion is large (>70 ml), perfusion imaging with CT or MRI may be considered.

 

Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) Acute Stroke Imaging Algorithm:

Acute Ischemic Stroke: Stroke is an acute episode of focal neurological dysfunction that persists for more than 24 hours.

Radiological Findings
CT Scan
  • Investigation of choice.
  • Characterized by cytotoxic edema, leading to significant but subtle changes in imaging.
  • This condition represents intracellular edema, which causes:
    • Loss of gray matter/white matter differentiation.
    • Effacement of cortical sulci.
  • Early ischemic lesion hypodensity on CT is the hallmark of acute brain infarction, indicating irreversible tissue damage and continual net water uptake.

  • Wedge shaped acute infarct.

  • A thrombus in the proximal middle cerebral artery (MCA) may be visible during the acute phase.
  • The thrombus appears as hyperattenuation on the CT scan.
  • Objectives of Non-Enhanced Cranial CT in Acute Stroke:
    • Exclude hemorrhage to allow aspirin therapy.
    • Exclude alternative causes of neurological deficit.
    • Assess infarct volume and calculate ASPECTS (Alberta Stroke Program Early CT Score).
    • Detecting a hyperdense vessel.
    • Confirm infarct matches the clinical timeline and is not subacute.
Diffusion-Weighted Imaging (DWI)
  • Has high sensitivity and specificity, detecting parenchymal hyperintensity as early as 5 minutes after infarction onset.
  • Determines area of penumbra.
  • DWI must be interpreted with an apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) map.
  • Restricted diffusion in acute infarct appears bright on DWI and dark on the ADC map.
  • In rare cases, DWI-positive areas may not progress to infarction after early recanalization treatments (IV agents or mechanical thrombectomy).

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents with sudden right-sided weakness and speech difficulty, starting 1 hour ago. A non-contrast CT scan is performed and is shown below. Which of the following signs is marked (arrow) in this case?
questions.solution:
Hyperdense basilar artery sign indicates the presence of an acute thrombus in the basilar artery. It is an early finding on a non-contrast CT scan in cases of posterior circulation stroke.

 

Hyperacute Ischemic Stroke: Patients who present within 6 hours of stroke onset fall into this category.

 

Radiologic Findings:

  • Top of basilar syndrome: Basilar artery may also appear dense in posterior circulation infarcts.

  • Dense Artery Sign: (Option D)
    • Earliest detectable sign on CT, caused by a fresh thrombus occluding the vessel.
    • Can be seen at the onset of stroke (ictus).
    • May rapidly disappear if the thrombus disperses.
    • Correlates with large infarcts and poor outcomes when found in the proximal MCA or terminal ICA.

  • Sylvian fissure dot sign (Option A): better prognosis if limited to an MCA branch within the Sylvian fissure.

 

  • Early Parenchymal Signs: reduced gray matter density and brain swelling manifesting as sulcal effacement.
  • In early MCA infarcts, reduced clarity of the lentiform nucleus and cortex, particularly in the insula, is observed.

 

  • Disappearing basal ganglia sign (Option B): Early indicator of middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction, characterized by the loss of delineation of the basal ganglia due to blurring of the gray-white matter interface.

  • Hypodensity in more than 50% of the MCA territory is associated with high mortality.
  • IV thrombolysis is contraindicated when more than one-third of the MCA territory is involved.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The emergency physician needs to determine the best initial imaging modality to assess for an acute ischemic stroke and potential hemorrhage. Which imaging technique should be performed first?
questions.solution:
Non-Contrast CT is the preferred initial imaging modality for evaluating acute ischemic stroke to rule out hemorrhage

 

Approach to Stroke:

Investigations of Stroke:

Non-Contrast CT (Option C)

CT Angiography (Option B)

MRI (Option A)
  • Earliest Signs of Ischemic Stroke: loss of differentiation between gray and white matter.
  • Loss of Insular Ribbon Sign: seen when the middle cerebral artery is involved, with the insula showing early changes.

  • Hyperdense Vessel Sign: In hyperacute strokes, the thrombus appears dense, causing hyperattenuation of the occluded segment of the MCA.
  • CT scan can also reveal whether there is bleeding in the brain or damage to brain cells resulting from a stroke.
  • Provides high-resolution imaging of the vascular tree from the aortic arch to intracranial vessels.
  • Allows for functional perfusion imaging and assessment of collaterals.
  • Earliest Signs of Ischemic Stroke: restricted diffusion on diffusion weighted imaging.
  • Is observed within a few minutes of arterial occlusion.
  • Can identify changes in brain tissue and damage to brain cells.
  • Uses:
    • Diagnosis of major stroke.
    • To identify a contraindication to treatment, like hemorrhage or large infarct.
    • To identify stroke mimic such as brain tumor.
  • Use:
    • Detection of large vessel occlusion (LVO).

   
  • Uses: 
    • Most sensitive technique for acute ischemic stroke detection.
    • Used in imaging diagnosis of minor stroke
    • Typically during follow-up.
  • CT perfusion (CTP) or perfusion computed tomography (PCT):
    • Time-resolved images of blood flow
    • Display format is perfusion maps, including cerebral blood flow, cerebral blood volume, and mean transit time.
    • Used to identify and quantify the volume of infarcted core and penumbra.
  • MR Angiography (Option D): Used in patients with a contraindication to contrast or a non-diagnostic CTA.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe headache and loss of consciousness. An MRI is performed shortly after the incident and shows a hyperintense lesion on T1-weighted images and a hypointense lesion on T2-weighted images, consistent with subacute hematoma. What would be the phase of blood in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario here is of an acute hemorrhage in the brain where the blood is in the deoxyhemoglobin phase.


 

Intracranial Hemorrhage Appearance on MRI:

 

  • The appearance of intracranial hemorrhage on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is influenced by:
    • The age of the hematoma.
    • The type of MRI sequence used (T1 or T2 weighted).
  • As a hematoma ages, hemoglobin transforms through several forms:
    • Oxyhemoglobin
    • Deoxyhemoglobin
    • Methemoglobin
    • Eventually breaking down into ferritin and hemosiderin.

 

Stages of Hemorrhage:

  • Hyperacute:
    • Characterized by intracellular oxyhemoglobin. (Option B)
  • Acute:
    • Features intracellular deoxyhemoglobin.
  • Early Subacute:
    • Contains intracellular methemoglobin. (Option C)
  • Late Subacute:
    • Comprises extracellular methemoglobin.
  • Chronic:
    • Consists of ferritin and hemosiderin. (Option D)

Magnetic Properties:

  • Magnetic susceptibility effects cause short T2 values observed in intracellular deoxyhemoglobin, methemoglobin, or hemosiderin.
  • T2 shortening can also occur due to hemoconcentration and clot retraction.

The most sensitive sequence of MRI detecting hemorrhage is susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) as it has a high sensitivity to blood products and hemosiderin.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with confusion and headache. A CT scan of the brain is performed which shows as follows:



The radiologist notes a characteristic appearance of increased spacing between the frontal lobes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT image in this scenario shows the classical “Mount Fuji” sign where the two frontal lobes take the appearance of mountain peaks which points to the diagnosis of pneumocephalus i.e., air within the cranial cavity.

 

Pneumocephalus/Tension pneumocephalus:

  • Pneumocephalus refers to the presence of air within the cranial cavity.
  • It most frequently occurs as a result of traumatic head injuries.
  • Tension pneumocephalus can be identified on imaging by:
    • Compression of the frontal lobes.
    • Increased spacing between the frontal lobes in the interhemispheric area.
  • This condition is commonly referred to as the "Mount Fuji sign" because its appearance resembles the famous mountain peak in Japan.

 

Carotid-cavernous fistula (Option D):

Classification: Carotid-cavernous fistulas (CCFs) are categorized as either direct or indirect.

  • Direct CCF: Involves a direct connection between the internal carotid artery (ICA) and the cavernous sinus.
  • Indirect CCF: Occurs when branches of the ICA or external carotid artery (ECA) connect to the cavernous sinus.

 

Causes:

  • Trauma: Skull base fractures or penetrating injuries
  • Spontaneous
  • Dural arteriovenous malformations
  • Rupture of an aneurysm
  • Fibromuscular hyperplasia

Symptoms:

  • Patients usually present with:
    • Unilateral pulsatile exophthalmos (protrusion of one eye)
    • Scleral injection (redness of the eye)
    • Chemosis (inflammation of the conjunctiva)

Imaging findings:

  • Venous distention is visible on ultrasound (USG), CT, CTA, MRI, and MRA.
  • Muscle enlargement is most noticeable on CT and MRI.

 

Diagnostic procedure:

CT angiography (CTA) is currently the preferred method for early detection of cavernous sinus and jugular vein enhancement.

 

 

Porencephalic cyst (Option A):

  • A porencephalic cyst is an unusual condition of the central nervous system characterized by a fluid-filled cavity within the cerebral hemisphere.
  • A CT scan of the brain reveals a hypodense intracranial cyst:
    • The cyst has a well-defined border.
    • Central attenuation is consistent with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
    • Typically, there is no mass effect on the surrounding brain tissue; however, very large cysts may exert local pressure.

 

  • An MRI of the brain demonstrates:
    • A clearly defined cyst coated with white matter.
    • Presence of gliosis may be noted, either with or without the cyst.
    • The cyst shows a signal consistent with cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Anterior communicating artery (ACOM) aneurysm (Option B):

  • Anterior communicating artery (ACOM) aneurysms are the most prevalent type of intracranial aneurysms.
  • The anatomical structure of the artery involves the size and shape of the aneurysm like the direction and calcification, and the presence or absence of of thrombosis.
  • They are particularly common in patients under 30 years of age.
  • ACOM aneurysms have a higher likelihood of rupture compared to other intracranial aneurysms due to specific anatomical and hemodynamic features.
  • ACOM aneurysms can compress the optic chiasm leading to symptoms like scotoma or blindness or bilateral hemianopsia and optic tract causing homonymous hemianopsia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He presents with loss of consciousness, altered mental status, decerebrate posturing, and widespread cerebral edema. A CT scan returns normal. After intubation, which MRI sequence is preferred for evaluating the extent of his neurological injuries?
questions.solution:
• In a patient with traumatic brain injury (TBI) presenting with loss of consciousness, altered mental status, decerebrate posturing, and diffuse cerebral edema, but with a normal CT scan, the most appropriate MRI sequence for evaluating the extent of neurological injuries is: Susceptibility-Weighted Imaging (SWI).

  • This sequence is highly sensitive for detecting microhemorrhages and diffuse axonal injury (DAI), which are common in high-velocity trauma.

  • CT scans often miss DAI, as the injuries can be microscopic or non-hemorrhagic.

 

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI)

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a type of traumatic brain injury that results from rapid acceleration and deceleration forces, commonly seen in cases of severe trauma, such as road traffic accidents (RTAs). It primarily affects the white matter of the brain, leading to widespread damage to axonal fibers.

 

Radiological Features

MRI

 

  • It is the investigation of choice for diagnosing diffuse axonal injury (DAI), particularly using Susceptibility Weighted Imaging (SWI). This sequence is sensitive to magnetic susceptibility changes, effectively detecting small hemorrhagic foci.
  • On SWI, black areas represent hemorrhage, appearing as blooming due to blood product accumulation, indicating diffuse axonal injury.
  • T2-weighted MRI is useful for assessing DAI, as it reveals hyperintense areas of axonal injury and edema, highlighting brain damage and secondary changes from the injury. However, T2-weighted MRI can sometimes be less sensitive to small hemorrhagic lesions
  • The combination of SWI and T2-weighted MRI enhances diagnostic accuracy, enabling a comprehensive evaluation of DAI and its structural effects on the brain.

 

CT Findings:

 

In most cases of DAI, CT scans may appear normal. However, in certain instances, they can show punctate hemorrhages, which are small spots of bleeding that indicate areas of axonal damage.

 

Clinical Presentation

Patients with DAI typically present with a poor or worsening Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score following trauma. This deterioration in consciousness is indicative of significant brain injury.

 

Adams grading classification for the severity of diffuse axonal injury (DAI)

 

The severity of DAI can be classified using Adams grading, which assesses the extent of axonal damage.

 

Grade

Location of Injury

Description

Prognosis

I

Gray matter and white matter interface

Involves the initial site of axonal injury.

Relatively better prognosis

II

Corpus callosum

Involves the critical structure connecting the two hemispheres. Suggests more severe disruption of axonal pathways.

Worse prognosis than Grade I

III

Brain stem

Involves the brain stem, which can significantly affect vital functions.

Associated with the worst prognosis

 

T1-weighted MRI (T1W) (Option A): T1-weighted images provide detailed anatomical information but are not optimal for visualizing edema and diffuse changes associated with widespread brain injury.

 

FLAIR MRI (Option B): While FLAIR imaging suppresses the signal from cerebrospinal fluid and can highlight certain lesions, it is not the primary sequence for detecting widespread edema and damage resulting from trauma.

 

Diffusion-weighted MRI (DWI) (Option D): DWI is useful for detecting early ischemic changes but may not provide the best assessment for the diffuse and complex injury patterns present in this scenario compared to T2-weighted imaging.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): On CT scan, the bone cortex appears black, while on MRI, it appears white.
Reason (R): The appearance of structures on CT and MRI depends on the density of tissues and the presence of hydrogen atoms.

choices.text: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true, and Reason (R) is the correct explanation of Assertion (A).
Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true, but Reason (R) is not the correct explanation of Assertion (A).
Assertion (A) is false, but Reason (R) is true.
Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are false.

questions.solution:
The statement is incorrect. On CT scan, the bone cortex appears white, not black. This is because CT scans measure tissue density, and bones are dense structures that absorb X-rays heavily, thus appearing white. On MRI, the bone cortex typically appears black due to the lack of free hydrogen atoms needed for generating MRI signals.


Reason: The reason is true, as the appearance of tissues on CT depends on tissue density (denser structures appear whiter), and on MRI, it depends on the presence of hydrogen atoms (more hydrogen results in a stronger signal).

Feature

CT (Computed Tomography)

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging)

Principle

Based on differential absorption of X-rays by tissues (denser tissues absorb more X-rays)

Based on the alignment of hydrogen protons in tissues in response to a magnetic field and radiofrequency pulses

Imaging Time

Faster

Slower, can take 30 minutes to over an hour
Bone cortex appearance:

White (due to dense bone absorbing X-rays)

Dark (lacks hydrogen protons)

Applications

Best for: Acute bleeding, skull fractures, calcifications, hyperacute stroke

Emergency use: Ideal for emergencies due to speed

Best for: Soft tissue details, brain tumors, demyelinating diseases, subacute/chronic ischemia

Emergency use: Not typically used in emergencies (except for soft tissue analysis)

Detection of Acute Hemorrhage

Highly sensitive for detecting acute hemorrhage

Less sensitive for acute hemorrhage, but can be used after a few days

Evaluation of Edema

Limited sensitivity to subtle edema

Excellent for detecting edema and differentiating tissue types

Stroke Detection

Good for detecting stroke in hyperacute phase (hours)

Better for detecting ischemia in subacute and chronic stages (days to weeks)

Contrast Agent Used

Iodine-based contrast agents (risk of allergy or kidney issues)

Gadolinium-based contrast agents (caution in renal failure)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a significant history of smoking presents with a sudden onset of a severe headache. He reports accompanying symptoms of palpitations, photophobia, and neck stiffness. On examination, signs of meningeal irritation are noted. The patient also has hyperflexible joints and mentions that his symptoms began after experiencing a minor jerk while in the car. A CT scan reveals specific findings given below. What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Meningitis secondary to a bacterial infection
Cervical spine injury leading to meningeal irritation
Migraine with aura exacerbated by the minor jerk

questions.solution:
Rupture of a cerebral aneurysm is the most common cause of sudden, severe headaches and is particularly associated with features suggestive of meningeal irritation, as seen in cases of subarachnoid hemorrhage. Individuals with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are at increased risk for vascular abnormalities, including cerebral aneurysms.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH)

 

Definition

Presence of blood in the subarachnoid space, typically from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm or trauma.

Clinical Features
  • Sudden, severe headache (often described as a "thunderclap headache")
  • Worst headache ever experienced by the patient.

Etiology
  • Traumatic: Head injuries causing bleeding in the subarachnoid space.
  • Non-Traumatic: Most commonly due to rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

Initial Imaging

Non-Contrast CT (NCCT): First-line imaging for suspected SAH, effective in the acute setting.
Radiological Findings (NCCT)

Appearance of Blood: Hyperdense (white) compared to surrounding cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

 

Common Sites for Blood Accumulation:

  • Interhemispheric Fissure
  • Sylvian Fissure
  • Suprasellar Cistern
  • Perimesencephalic Cistern


Distinctive Shape: Blood may take on a pentagon or star shape, referred to as the "Star of Death."

Additional Investigations

CT Angiography: Visualizes potential aneurysms or vascular malformations; useful for rupture suspicion.

Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA): Gold standard for diagnosing cerebral aneurysms; provides detailed vascular images and therapeutic options (e.g., endovascular coiling).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents after a road traffic accident. He experienced a brief loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval. On examination, he has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 13 and exhibits signs of a head injury. A CT scan of the head was performed, and the image revealed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
EDH is often caused by trauma, such as in this road traffic accident, leading to disruption of the middle meningeal artery. The classic presentation includes a brief loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval, typical for EDH. Here the CT, shows a biconvex (lentiform) shaped hematoma that does not cross suture lines. A GCS score of 13 indicates mild impairment, consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Feature

Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH)

Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH) (Option A)

Type of Hemorrhage

Arterial Hemorrhage

Venous Hemorrhage
Shape

Biconvex or lentiform

Crescent or sickle-shaped

Location

Limited by sutures; can cross the midline

Follows the brain surface; crosses sutures, does not cross midline

Cause

Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (MMA)

Rupture of cortical bridging veins

Onset of Symptoms

Often presents with a lucid interval

Symptoms may develop gradually, often without a lucid interval

Force Required

Requires more force; associated with adjacent bony rupture

Can occur with trivial trauma

Midline Crossing

Can cross the midline

Does not cross the midline

Lucid Interval

Yes; patient appears normal before deterioration

No; deterioration may be more gradual

Clinical Signs

Symptoms may include headache, loss of consciousness, and focal neurological deficits

Symptoms may include headache, confusion, and potential focal deficits

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) (Option C): SAH presents with bleeding in the subarachnoid space and shows diffuse blood in the sulci and cisterns rather than a localized collection.

 

Cerebral contusion (Option D): Cerebral contusions typically appear as areas of brain parenchymal damage and do not exhibit the characteristic biconvex shape seen in this case.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a head injury sustained during a fall. He is alert, opens his eyes to speech, follows commands, and is oriented but complains of a mild headache. On assessment, he opens his eyes spontaneously, is verbally coherent but slightly disoriented, and follows motor commands. There are no focal neurological deficits, bleeding disorders, seizures, or intoxication. Based on the clinical findings and his GCS score, what is the next appropriate step in management?

choices.text: Observation with repeat neurological assessment every 4 hours

questions.solution:
Observation with repeat neurological assessment every 4 hours, The patient has a GCS score of 13 (Eye = 4, Verbal = 4, Motor = 5), indicating a mild head injury. As there are no additional risk factors per the ACR guidelines, the next best step is close observation with repeated neurological assessments rather than immediate imaging.

 

CT Imaging Guidelines for Head Trauma
 

GCS Score

TBI Severity

13-15

Mild TBI

9-12

Moderate TBI

3-8

Severe TBI

 

In cases of penetrating cranial injury, a head CT is recommended immediately, regardless of GCS.

 

Indications for Head CT

For patients with mild to moderate TBI (GCS 13-12), the decision to perform a CT scan depends on the presence of additional risk factors. The ACR guidelines state that a head CT should be performed if any one of the following "ABCDEF" criteria are met.

  • Age >60 years
  • Blood coagulopathy
  • Clavicle or supra-clavicular injury
  • Drugs or neurological deficits
  • Epilepsy or post-traumatic seizure
  • Focal neurological deficits
  • Generic brain-related complaints (e.g., headache, vomiting)

These additional findings serve as red flags, warranting imaging to prevent delayed diagnosis of significant brain injuries.

 

Severe TBI or Penetrating Injury

In the context of severe TBI (GCS 3-8) or penetrating cranial injury, a head CT is indicated immediately due to the high risk of life-threatening intracranial injuries.


 

Immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation (Option A): This option is incorrect as intubation is typically reserved for patients with severe traumatic brain injury (GCS ≤ 8) or those at risk of airway compromise. The patient's GCS of 13, indicating a mild head injury, does not meet the criteria for intubation.

 

CT scan of the head (Option B): According to the American College of Radiology (ACR) guidelines, a head CT scan is typically reserved for patients with a GCS score between 13-15 if additional risk factors are present, a CT scan is not immediately necessary.


Initiate anticonvulsant therapy (Option D): Anticonvulsants are not routinely indicated unless there is a history of seizures or a high risk of post-traumatic seizures, which the patient does not exhibit here.

questions.text: A patient comes with his MR angiography brain report to the clinic. Identify the marked artery in this image.
questions.solution:
The image here shows the circle of Willis, and the artery marked is the basilar artery which arises from the joining of both left and right vertebral arteries.

Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA)

There are various types of MR angiograms based on different principles and can be classified into non-contrast and contrast enhanced methods.

Non-contrast MRA

Contrast enhanced (CE) MRA

Time-of-flight (TOF) imaging:

  • It is the most prevalent method for Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) in clinical practice.

Phase-contrast MRA:

  • It is more sensitive for identifying slow blood flow and useful for imaging cerebral veins (MR venography or MRV).
  • Effective for detecting dural venous sinus thrombosis and venous stenoses.
  • MRA combined with gadolinium-based contrast agents is called contrast-enhanced (CE) MRA.
     
  • Excellent for quickly visualizing the carotid and vertebral arteries where a large field of view (FOV) is necessary.
     
  • Reduces artifacts caused by turbulent or slow flow.
     
  • Useful for assessing arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), aneurysms, and intracranial stenosis.
  • Two types are:
    • Elliptical-centric
    • Multiphase techniques

Anterior cerebral artery (Option A) is found at the anterior-most of the circle of Willis arising from the internal carotid artery (marked as 1 in the image).

 

Vertebral artery (Option B) is a branch of the subclavian artery that joins together from both sides to form the basilar artery (marked as 8 in the image).


Middle cerebral artery (Option C) is not a part of the circle of Willis and originates from the internal carotid artery (marked as 2 in the image).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the given image is not true?

choices.text: It is a standard investigation alongside non-contrast CT for diagnosing stroke
It is used to resolve discrepancies in findings from noninvasive imaging
It diagnoses spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage when CTA results are negative
It can be used for embolization of AVMs and fistulas

questions.solution:
The given image shows Digital subtraction angiography(DSA). CT angiography is used as a standard investigation along with non-contrast CT for the diagnosis in acute stroke protocols and not DSA.

 

Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA)

Clinical applications
  • Acute stroke protocols: CTA is a standard investigation alongside non-contrast CT and CT perfusion (CTP) for evaluating stroke.
  • It is used to detect dynamic contrast extravasation indicative of active hemorrhage.
  • It is highly sensitive (>90%) for intracranial aneurysms, particularly in subarachnoid hemorrhage cases.
  • It is also effective for assessing carotid artery stenosis, cervical artery dissection, and intracranial vascular stenosis

Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA)

Applications
  • Resolve discrepancies in findings from noninvasive imaging (CTA or MRA). (Option B)
  • Diagnosing spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage when CTA results are negative. (Option C)
  • Evaluate younger patients with intraparenchymal hemorrhage for underlying arteriovenous malformations (AVMs).
  • DSA supports a variety of endovascular treatments, including:
    • Clot retrieval for acute ischemic stroke
    • Treatment of brain aneurysms (coiling, stenting, flow diversion)
    • Embolization of AVMs and fistulas (Option D)
    • Tumor embolization and stenting of intracranial arterial stenoses
    • Intra-arterial therapies for vasospasm

questions.text:
Match the following structures with their corresponding CT score.

 


	
		
			
			Structure
			
			
			CT score in HU
			
		
		
			
			a) Air
			
			
			1) 0
			
		
		
			
			b) Water
			
			
			2) -1000
			
		
		
			
			c) Grey Matter
			
			
			3) 700 to 3000
			
		
		
			
			d) Bone
			
			
			4) 37 to 45
questions.solution:
Structure

CT score in HU

a) Air

1) -1000

b) Water

2) 0

c) Grey Matter

3) 37 to 45

d) Bone

4) 700 to 3000


 

Housenfield unit (HU):

  • In each slice of a CT scan, every tiny cube of tissue (called a voxel) is given a CT number. This number is based on how much the x-rays are blocked by that tissue, compared to distilled water at 0°C and 1 bar of pressure, and is measured in Hounsfield Units (HU).
  • The ones with a lower CT number appear the darkest, and the ones with a higher CT number appear brighter.
  • The values of some structures are as follows:

 

Structure

CT score (HU)

Air

-1000

Water

0

CSF

8 to 15

White matter

20 to 30

Blood

30 to 45

Grey matter

37 to 45

Contrast

100 to 300

Bone

700 (cancellous) to 3000 (inner and outer tables)

questions.text: A student is analyzing an MRI of the brain at the midbrain level. The examiner asks the student to identify the structure marked as “a”. What is this structure?
questions.solution:
The hypodense structure marked in the image is the anterior cerebral artery.

MRI BRAIN

CT BRAIN

  • This uses the alignment of hydrogen protons in tissues in response to a magnetic field and radiofrequency pulses.
  • The skull bone cortex appears black/dark in the MRI.

 
  • X-rays that penetrate the head or other parts of the body produce images based on tissue density and atomic number.
  • The bone cortex can be seen as a hyperintense (white) area.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male presents with persistent headaches and cognitive decline. An MRI reveals a suspicious mass in the parietal lobe. To further characterize the mass, an MR spectroscopy (MRS) is performed which shows:



 Which of the following interpretations is most accurate regarding the metabolic changes observed in MR spectroscopy?

choices.text: The elevated choline levels suggest high cellular turnover
The decreased NAA indicates significant neuronal viability
The absence of any metabolites in the spectrum indicates healthy brain tissue
Raised creatinine levels show low metabolic activity

questions.solution:
The MR spectroscopy analyzes the metabolites in various tissues and choline is a metabolite suggesting increased cellular turnover.

 

MR Spectroscopy
  • It is a technique used to analyze metabolites in various tissues, including the brain, breast, and prostate done at 1.5 or 3T.
  • Measures levels of lactate, lipids, and choline within a specific volume of tissues.

Metabolite Markers
  • N-acetyl aspartate (NAA): indicates neuronal viability. (Option B)
  • Choline: represents cell membrane composition and cellular turnover.
  • Creatine: found in metabolically active tissues, serving as a reference. (Option D)
  • Lipids: released during cell membrane damage.
  • Lactate: signifies anaerobic metabolism.
  • In a normal brain, these metabolites are present in the order: NAA > creatinine > choline. (Option C)

Clinical Applications
  • Choline is raised in malignancies.
  • Lipids are raised in TB due to mycolipids of mycobacterium.
  • MRS is used for assessing brain tumors, including:
    • Grading of tumors.
    • Monitoring tumor progression versus treatment effects.
    • Diagnosing infectious and metabolic diseases.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with progressive memory loss and word-finding difficulty shows language deficits on a neurological exam. The physician orders an MRI to map language centers before treatment. Which MRI technique is most appropriate for this?
questions.solution:
A functional MRI is used to assess the brain function related to specific tasks and hence it is used to detect the language center in the brain in this scenario and also in preoperative assessments.

 

Functional MRI (fMRI)
  • It is used for noninvasive mapping of brain function related to specific tasks (e.g., motor, language, visual, memory).
  • It provides insights into functional localization, anatomical variations, and the effects of diseases and adaptations and is important for preoperative assessments in tumors, arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), and epilepsy surgery.

Principle

Increased neural activity during a task

￬

Localized rise in blood flow for oxygen and glucose supply

￬

￪ Oxygenated hemoglobin (oxyHb)

￬deoxygenated hemoglobin (deoxyHb)

￬

Changes in magnetization

￬

Measured by blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) effect.

 
  • The comparison between the BOLD effect measured at rest and while doing a particular function gives the precise functional localization of nerve cells to be color-mapped.

Applications

  • Detects functionality in diseases like Alzheimer’s.
  • Presurgical assessment for brain tumor and AVM surgeries.
  • Preepilepsy surgery assessment of language centre localization and hemispheric dominance.

 

Diffusion Tensor Imaging (DTR)/Tractography (Option A):

  • It is a variation of the diffusion-weighted imaging technique.
  • This is useful in analyzing the principal white matter pathways in the brain, connections of various regions of the brain, and their disorders.

Susceptibility- Weighted Imaging (SWI) (Option B)
  • It incorporates T2*-signal intensity losses in images.
  • This is highly sensitive for detecting variations in tissue structure caused by differences in susceptibility.
  • Effectively identifies substances such as
    • Deoxygenated blood
    • Hemosiderin
    • Ferritin
    • Calcium

T2*
  • T2* (T2 star) relaxation is the time taken for the decay of transverse magnetization in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), including both the irreversible T2 relaxation and additional reversible dephasing processes.
  • T2* is always less than T2.

 

Perfusion-Weighted Imaging (PWI) (Option D):

  • Perfusion-weighted imaging encompasses three methods for assessing brain tissue perfusion.
  • It provides information about:
    • Cerebral blood volume (CBV)
    • Cerebral blood flow (CBF)
    • Mean transit time (MTT)
    • Capillary permeability, which is elevated in conditions like gliomas, metastases, and inflammatory lesions
    • Areas of reduced perfusion (oligemic or ischemic brain tissue)
  • Measures tissue blood flow without the need for contrast injection.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of weakness for an hour on one side of his body. He has a history of deep vein thrombosis but is not compliant with his medications. A CT scan is performed, which shows no acute hemorrhage. An MRI of the brain was performed below.



Which MRI sequence is most appropriate for detecting early ischemic changes in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above scenario points to an acute stroke due to an acute infarct causing ischemia which is best diagnosed with diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) MRI as it can detect infarcts within minutes of onset. The image also points out that it is DWI since in this method the skull is not visualized.

 

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging)

Principle
  • When the patient is placed in an MRI machine, the protons in the body arrange themselves in a specific fashion, that is, parallel or antiparallel to the external magnetic field (B₀).
  • When radiofrequency (FR) waves are passed through the patient, they induce the MR coil/antenna, which is digitally processed into images.
  • The time between each RF pulse is called the repetition time (TR).
  • The time taken between the excitation of protons to the reading of an echo signal is called echo time (TE).

Contraindications

  • Absolute:
    • Cardiac pacemaker
    • Cochlear implants
    • Aneurysmal clips
  • Relative:
    • Claustrophobia
    • Tattoos
    • Recent metal implants & prosthetics
    • Dental implants

 

T1 weighted vs T2 weighted MRI:

  • The tissue appearance in MRI is either hyperintense or hypointense relative to the gray matter.

T1 weighted MRI (Option A)

T2 weighted MRI (Option C)

  • T1 is the time taken for the longitudinal magnetization to return to 63% of its original value.

Observations:

  • Hyperintense:
    • White matter is more intense than gray matter
    • Fat appears bright
    • Cerebrospinal fluid is of low-intensity
  • Hypointense:
    • Melanin
    • Proteinaceous material
    • Gadolinium-based contrast agents
    • Late subacute hemorrhage

  • T2 is the time taken for the transverse magnetization to decay to 37% of its original value.

Observations:

  • Hyperintense:
    • Cerebrospinal fluid
    • Pathologies involving increased tissue water content
  • Hypointense:
    • White matter is hypointense compared to gray matter
    • Fat
  • It has a short TR and TE
  • It has a long TR and TE 

 

Newer technologies in MRI

Diffusion-Weighted Imaging (DWI)
  • Any pathology that affects the dispersion of water is detected by this method.
  • The shift of extracellular fluid into the intracellular space causes restricted Brownian motion and gets detected as restricted diffusion in the DWI.
  • The skull is not visualized in this method.
 

Applications:

  • Acute brain infarction:
    • The failure of the sodium-potassium ATP pump leads to cytotoxic edema.
    • Detected within minutes of onset.
  • Ischemia is seen as a bright lesion.
  • Regions of active demyelination.
  • Infections like cerebral abscess.
  • Cellular tumors like glioblastoma and lymphoma.

Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery (FLAIR) (Option B)
  • This is useful in identifying:
    • Demyelinating plaques
    • Edema
    • Infarcts after 6 hours
    • Differentiation of arachnoid cyst from other complex cysts
  • Hyperintensity may be seen in cerebral or cerebellar sulci due to:
    • Blood product in subarachnoid hemorrhage
    • Pus in meningitis
    • Leptomeningeal spread of tumor
    • Artefact due to oxygen administration during the scanning.
